awd_titl_txt: FRG: Collaborative Research: Model Theory of Differential and Difference Equations with Applications
awd_abstract_narration:
This project is concerned with differential equations, which relate a quantity to its rate of change with respect to continuous time; difference equations, which relate a quantity to its rate of change with respect to discrete time; and combinations of these. Systems of such equations describe or model behavior and phenomena throughout the sciences; epidemiology, population dynamics, mechanics etc. The project will use methods from model theory, a branch of mathematical logic, to develop or improve procedures for showing consistency (existence of solutions) of systems of such equations, for identifying auxiliary parameters in systems of such equations, and for eliminating unknowns from such systems. The project will also extend the existing classification of sets of solutions from the case of over-determined (or finite-dimensional) systems to under-determined (or infinite-dimensional systems). 

In this focused research group project, the team of researchers studies differential, difference, and differential-difference equations, from the point of view of model theory in the sense of mathematical logic. Among the aims is to provide decision procedures or improve existing decision procedures regarding consistency and elimination. Applications to a variety of modelling problems for physical systems are expected. The proposed research is threefold. The first is to develop efficient algorithms in cases where the existing methods from theories of differential or difference fields provide algorithms in principle. The second is to extend the existing model-theoretic classification of finite-dimensional solution spaces of systems to infinite-dimensional solution spaces, as well as developing methods to apply the classification in practice. The third is to introduce and study new first order theories of rings with operators, whose decision procedures will apply to new examples arising in applications.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
One of the main outcomes of the project was very new results in identifying parameters in what are called ODE models; certain systems of ordinary differential equations which are used to describe various processes from biology, chemistry,...   Included are linear compartmental models, and predator prey models.  In these systems there are input variables, output variables, and state variables, all functions of time. There are also some real numbers which are called the parameters. In linear compartmental models, such parameters describe the rate of flow between various compartments (such as the heart and the bloodstream).   The aim of parameter identifiability is to determine whether parameters can be identified from the input and output data (the observables), and if not, which functions of the parameters can be so identified.  Here the input and output data are represented by  estimating the corresponding functions by measuring the value at a certain number of times (an experiment).  

The PI (and collaborators) introduced the notion of "multi-experiment" identifiability, in contrast to single experiment identifiability. 

The PI's introduce a notion, input-output identifiability, which means a rational functon in the coefficients of the input-output equations. They show that input-output identifiability is equivalent to multit-experiment identifiability, and give an example to show that these need not agree with single experiment identifiability.  Also it is shown how to compute the appropriate number of experimentts. 

In the two published papers on the topic, this is all performed explicitly and algorithmically. 

Part of the novelty of the work is that methods come from model theory, part of mathematical logic.

 

Other outcomes  of the project were somewhat more abstract than what is described above.  One of the aspects is describing relations between solutions of systems of solutions of ordinary differential equations. This is often called functional transcendence.  Another related aspect is describing symmetries of the set of solutions of some such system. This is  often called the Galois theory of differential equations.  The PI obtained a variety of new results on these topics. 

The project also supported some junior researchers as posdoctoral scholars, and supported the participation  mainly US-based researchers at an international conference on differential algebra.
